thread.title: Rangers better be ready for 'The Duke' - Hockey
thread.title_full: Rangers better be ready for 'The Duke' - Hockey - NorthJersey.com

author: ANDREW GROSS
title: Rangers better be ready for 'The Duke' - Hockey
text:
The Duke of the Desert returns to Madison Square Garden on Thursday night and the timing probably isn’t the best for the Rangers.
Anthony Duclair is off to a terrific start with the Coyotes, who open a five-game road trip against the Devils tonight, and Keith Yandle, like the rest of the Rangers defensemen, has had his struggles.
Which is not a second-guess of the March 1 swap, when then-Rangers GM Glen Sather went all-in on his Stanley Cup pursuit and agreed to include Duclair, his top prospect, along with a first- and second-round pick to acquire the offensive-minded defenseman and power-play quarterback the team craved.
But it is a reminder the Rangers have overpaid in their recent trade deadline dealings, including the previous year’s swap of two first-rounders and Ryan Callahan for the now-retired Marty St. Louis.
"Anytime you make a trade for a player, especially [a guy like Yandle], who’s been an elite player, you’ve got to give up," said Rangers coach Alain Vigneault, who famously dubbed Duclair "The Duke" during his short stint on Broadway last season.
"There’s no doubt we gave up a lot."
Duclair, 20, has four goals and two assists in five games, including his first career hat trick, and is tied with fellow rookie and linemate Max Domi for second on the team with six points.
Duclair had a wonderful training camp with the Rangers prior to last season, forcing his way onto the opening night roster.
He scored one goal with six assists in 18 games before the Rangers loaned him to Team Canada for the World Junior Championships, then returned him to his junior club, the Quebec Remparts, before Sather relented and enticed Coyotes GM Don Maloney to trade Yandle by including him in the deal.
That deal was about the present for the win-now Rangers – still their status this season. There are no guarantees Duclair would have earned as much playing time with the Rangers as he’s getting in Arizona.
Still, it’ll be hard not to imagine the what-ifs when Duclair takes to the Garden ice this week.
Not only did Yandle start the season slowly, but he’s an impending unrestricted free agent. The Rangers may not be able to afford him without some serious salary cap maneuvering.
"I know Keith is extremely passionate and is putting a lot of pressure on himself to perform well," Vigneault said. "I think it’s just a matter of time before we see it on a more consistent basis."
The Coyotes are seeing it from Duclair at the moment.
Email: grossa@northjersey.com
